unicode.value: Communication in Distributed Systems and Applications
Communication in Distributed Systems and Applications
Communication in Distributed Systems and Applications

Protocols are the basis of every distributed system or application. However, there are some disadvantages when it comes to the design and development of complex distributed applications.

Firstly, network protocols are based on message-oriented communication and do not allow other communication models. Furthermore, a higher degree of abstraction is advantageous when designing distributed applications. Accordingly, network protocols offer many details per se, but at the lowest level. Thus they also violate the concept of transparency.

This is where middleware provides common services and protocols for the development of distributed applications, e.g.:

  • high‐level communication services ( e.g. Remote Procedure Call)
  • security protocols (e.g for authentication and authorization)
  • distributed locking protocols for mutual exclusion
  • distributed commit protocols

To work through this content you need the Distributed Systems book by Steen and Tanenbaum.

Steen, M. van, & Tanenbaum, A. S. (2017). Distributed systems (Third edition (Version 3.01 (2017))). Pearson Education.

You can obtain the book free of charge from Maarten van Steen's website.

https://www.distributed-systems.net/index.php/books/ds3/

The book is also available as a printed book via Amazon.

We can distinguish between the following basic forms of communication:

  • Persistent vs. transient communication
  • Asynchronous communication - the sender continues its computation immediately after the transmission of its message
  • Synchronous communication - the sender is blocked until its message is stored in a local buffer at the recipient host or delivered to the recipient.

E.g. Client/server communication is usually based on synchronous communication. This has disadvantages:

  • The client cannot perform any other work while waiting for a response
  • Failures must be dealt with immediately
  • in many cases this model just not appropriate as client and server have to be active at the time of communication (e.g. e-mail or messengers)

Duration:
10:00

If you would like to review some of the basics of network protocols, please read the infobox Note 4.1 in the Distributed systems book starting on page 167.

Many distributed applications are directly implemented on a simple message-oriented model provided by the transport layer. The implementation takes place directly at this level in form of a communication protocol implementation, without middleware technologies and therefore at a low level of abstraction.

The programming interface for this is the Berkeley Socket API, or in the case of environments such as Java or .Net, a derived environment.

A higher level of abstraction is provided by message queuing, which we will address in the next section.

Please do not associate the term socket directly with WebSockets. The WebSocket protocol is a network protocol designed to establish a bidirectional connection between a web application and a WebSocket server or a web server that also supports WebSockets. The starting point is always an HTTP connection. Websockets will be discussed in detail later.

Duration:
20:00

Please read chapter 4.3 Message-oriented communication, pages 193-198.
Messages on a higher level of abstraction

Message queue systems use a queue for messages and include management functions to pass on control or content.

They also provide an asynchronous communication model. This means that the sender and recipient of the message do not have to interact with the message queue at the same time. Messages that are placed in the queue are stored until the recipient retrieves them.

Most messaging systems support both the Publisher/Subscriber pattern and the Message Queue model in their API.

Duration:
20:00

Please read chapter 4.3 Message-oriented communication, pages 199-203 and 206-2012.
RMI and RPC as an alternative to the message-oriented paradigm.

"Many distributed systems have been based on explicit message exchange between processes. However, the operations send and receive do not conceal communication at all, which is important to achieve access transparency in distributed systems [...] In a nutshell, the proposal was to allow programs to call procedures located on other machines." [1, p.  173]

[1] Steen, M. van, & Tanenbaum, A. S. (2017). Distributed systems (Third edition (Version 3.01 (2017))). Pearson Education.

Duration:
15:00

Please read chapter 4.2 Remote procedure call, pages 173-188.
